Right, we would need to:

1. Deprecate it in the help.
2. Output a warning to stderr if the option is used.
3. After one release cycle where the option is deprecated, it would be eligible for removal in major release after that.
@ijuma thanks ! So I'm going to close this PR and the related JIRA for now then Opening a new JIRA for marking the option as deprecated with related new PR.
Call for review @bbejeck @dguy @enothereska @guozhangwang

@junrao I have carefully reviewed the patch three times and made all the improvements I can think of. All system tests and integration tests have passed. Would you have time to review the patch sometime this week? Thank you!

There is only one improvement that I haven't made in this patch. Currently the producer will still send ProduceRequest with version 3 if the message magic version is 2. This is because the newly-added produce version 4 is incompatible with 0.11 broker. The downside of this is that server will translate KafkaStorageException to NotLeaderForPartitionException. But this should not cause any problem to the functionality of the producer. We can fix this in a followup patch if needed.

I am not able to see the details of the build failure where you mentioned pure virtual error. However I am still getting the AssertionError on the RHEL machine:

```
org.apache.kafka.streams.state.internals.RocksDBStoreTest > shouldThrowProcessorStateExceptionOnOpeningReadOnlyDir FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Expected exception: org.apache.kafka.streams.errors.ProcessorStateException
```

Thanks @vahidhashemian. Have we considered rethrowing the same exception with the original exception as the cause? Ideally, we would add a method to the future that does that so that the logic doesn't have to be repeated in multiple places. Using `addSuppressed` kind of works although it seems a little bit of a hack. See the Javadoc: ```java *

Note that when one exception {@linkplain * #initCause(Throwable) causes} another exception, the first * exception is usually caught and then the second exception is * thrown in response. In other words, there is a causal * connection between the two exceptions. * * In contrast, there are situations where two independent * exceptions can be thrown in sibling code blocks, in particular * in the {@code try} block of a {@code try}-with-resources * statement and the compiler-generated {@code finally} block * which closes the resource. * * In these situations, only one of the thrown exceptions can be * propagated. In the {@code try}-with-resources statement, when * there are two such exceptions, the exception originating from * the {@code try} block is propagated and the exception from the * {@code finally} block is added to the list of exceptions * suppressed by the exception from the {@code try} block. As an * exception unwinds the stack, it can accumulate multiple * suppressed exceptions. ```

@guozhangwang you do want different configs for different internal topics. Changelog topics backing in-memory lru caches will have different settings than changelog topics for windowed stores (i.e. you probably want shorter retention and smaller segments to trigger sooner compaction for lru, different timestamp policies based on arrival vs. event time).

@xvrl My previous question was that is it common to require different topic configs for the repartition topics. The current mechanism is that:

0. Kafka server side topics config is global for all possible topics ever created.
1. The streams config is global (i.e. this PR) that affects all internal topics being created, including the repartition and changelog topics.
2. The `StateStoreSupplier` allows you to override the configs for its changelog topics.
3. For repartition topics we do not yet have a way to override it on a per-topic basis.

So my question was mainly around 3) above whether it is as common as a requirement to override per-topic as for the changelog topics.

For `stream-processor-node-metrics` the task id is encoded in the attribute name, but for cache metrics they are encoded in the identified as `record-cache-id=1_0-Counts`, and for store metrics they are not encoded at all (i.e. multiple tasks' stores will be sharing the same metric). It is not consistent.

![screen shot 2017-07-17 at 2 43 20 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10729597/28291234-7284f82c-6afe-11e7-9dc3-0566bdba3060.png)

All metrics have the `client-id=[thread-name]` but not for `stream-record-cache-metrics`. This is not consistent:

![screen shot 2017-07-17 at 2 43 20 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10729597/28291245-7cca2596-6afe-11e7-9888-c8dc1d48123d.png)
cc @miguno

LGTM overall. One thing that is missing (from a previous PR) is that in `docs/toc.html` the ref links are still pointing to some hrefs within the streams page which are already gone. Could you update them as well? ```
  • 9. Kafka Streams
    • 9.1 Overview
    • 9.2 Core Concepts
    • 9.3 Architecture
    • 9.4 Developer Guide
      • Low-Level Processor API
      • High-Level Streams DSL
      • Application Configuration and Execution
    • 9.5 Upgrade Guide and API Changes
    • ```

@guozhangwang just because it's not documented doesn't mean people will not catch them. Typically users will want to make their code resilient against any exception they've encountered in practice. Especially if they experience undocumented exception, they will be more likely to act defensively and try to catch anything. Can we at least document under what circumstances they might encounter streams or Kafka exception and what the user is expected to do in those cases?

Merged to trunk and 0.11.0 after adding the assertion requested by @junrao. @rajinisivaram, maybe you can submit a follow-up for Jun's suggestion:

> Also, in SocketServer, it may be better to catch unexpected exceptions within the loop of socket key iteration in places like processCompletedReceives(). That way, if we hit an unexpected exception, it only affects a single key. This can be done in a separate patch though.
@ijuma since this requires adding a new section to the upgrade notes, I'm going to assume the next release is 1.0.0.

@guozhangwang I think it is good practice to assume that Kafka server side default topic configuration is out of reach to most streams users. That leaves the global streams config and state store configuration.

We can probably get away with the defaults most of the time for repartition topics.
I can however see overriding some settings being useful in some cases:
- when dealing with mixed timestamps, some parts of the topology may rely on log-append-time, vs. other parts may use create-time policies, e.g. input data may be log-append-time, but once you aggregate the data you may want to rely on create-time.
- to control data retention: repartition topics are an unfortunate necessity, but technically only required to get data into the right partitions, which makes them somewhat wasteful. For large topics, having control over retention settings is useful to avoid wasting too much space. 
- when dealing with different amounts of data in different parts of the topology, adjusting the number of partitions on some parts of the topology might be useful. e.g. large amounts of data could benefit from a larger number of partitions, but if the data gets reduced throughout the topology it becomes useful to lower the number of partitions to avoid an unnecessary large number of state stores.
@guozhangwang updated the TOC to point at the new Streams landing page. Will put in a matching PR for kafka-site
